Alarm System.  A common trouble alarm is provided both to the main control panel and DCS on any of the following conditions:
· Low storage tank level - the storage tank low pressure alarm indicating that the vaporizer system has malfunctioned is provided in the DCS .  The alarm also is used to indicate that the storage tank needs to be refilled.
· High storage tank level - the storage tank high pressure alarm indicating that that the vaporizer system has malfunctioned, or an excessive high ambient temperature is provided in the Main control and DCS. The alarm also indicates when the anhydrous ammonia unloading should stop. 
· Leakage of ammonia from the inner shell of the storage tank - In the event of leak detection by the pressure switch installed in the annular space, an alarm indicating high pressure in the annular space is annunciated in the DCS. 
· Leakage from the hose during unloading - in the event of leakage from the hose(s) during unloading an operator shall use the emergency button on the unloading panel or the remote emergency button on the west side of the STG building wall to close the unloading valves.  The operator will then close the shutoff valves on the bulk delivery vehicle.

Hot Work Permit 
RMP, CalARP, and Cal-OSHA regulations require employees and contractors to employ safe work practices when performing hot work in, on, or around the anhydrous ammonia process.  To ensure that hot work is done safely, a hot work permits program must be developed that requires that a permit be issued before hot work is performed.  The purpose of hot work permits program is to provide accountability and documentation necessary for ensuring the safe performance of hot work during normal operations, maintenance and construction operations. Hot work permits document that the fire prevention and protection requirements in 8 CCR 6777 have been implemented prior to beginning the hot work operations.  The hot work permits program also applies to any contractor work conducted at this facility.  The site shall utilize hot the work permit procedures as defined in Calpine's Hot Work Procedure.
Contractors 
DEC has procedures and policies in place that ensure that only contractors with good safety programs are selected to perform work on and around the ammonia process.  Contractors are properly informed of the hazards, access limitations to these process areas, and emergency response procedures, and are prepared to safely complete the work.  DEC sets minimum contractor safety performance requirements for work in process areas, holds contractor safety briefings before allowing them near or in the process area, control

Management of Change 
DEC provides a system and approach to maintain and implement management of changes or modifications to equipment, procedures, chemicals, and processing conditions.  This system allows our employees to identify and review safety hazards or provide additional safety, process, or chemical information before the proposed change is implemented. Effective management will help minimize the chance for an accidental release.  A system that manages changes made to the ammonia process will allow changes to be identified and reviewed before they are implemented to determine if the proposed change would compromise system safety. The site will utilize the MOC procedures defined in in the Management of Change portion of DEC's RMP plan.
Pre-Startup Safety Review 
DEC ensures that a pre-startup safety review is completed for any new regulated process at the plant, or for significant modifications to an existing covered process that requires a change in the process safety information.  The prestartup safety review confirms the following:
· Equipment has been installed in accordance with design specifications
· Adequate safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place 
·  A PHA has been performed and recommendations resolved or implemented for new processes
· Facility and/or process modifications meet the requirements of Management of Change procedure
· Training for each employee involved in operating and maintaining the process has been completed
1.6  Five-Year Accident History Summary
DEC has had no accidents or releases involving ammonia in the past five years.

Employee Participation 
The Calpine Corporation recognizes that the participation of the DEC staff in preparing this RMP/PSM program is critical to the plan's successful implementation. The facility's Employee Participation Plan is designed to fulfill the regulatory requirements of a written plan of action for implementing employee participation requirements.  In addition, the plan serves as written documentation demonstrating the required accessibility of pertinent information to employees.  Employee participation is valuable because it increases the safety awareness of the staff and it allows the staff's experience in operating and maintaining the processes to be incorporated into the plan, especially the process hazard analysis.

Compliance Audits
Internal compliance audits are conducted every three years to verify compliance with the programs and procedures contained in the RMP.  DEC hires a consultant knowledgeable in the Risk Management Program rule and in the regulatory process.  This consultant evaluates whether the prevention program satisfies the requirements of the RMP rule and whether the prevention program is sufficient to help ensure safe operation.  The results of the audit are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate enhancements to the prevention program are implemented.
A site audit of the Risk Management/Process Safety Plan was performed on March 23, 2021.  Due to restrictions imposed by COVID-19, the audit was conducted remotely using MS Teams platform to meet and share information.

Training 
Each DEC employee presently involved in operating or maintaining the ammonia process is trained in an overview of the process and applicable operating and maintenance procedures.  Training helps employees understand the nature and cause of problems arising from operations involving ammonia, and increases employee awareness of hazards.  DEC training program includes both initial and triennial refresher training that covers:  (1) a general overview of the processes, (2) the properties and hazards of the substances in the process, and (3) a detailed review of the process operating procedures and safe work practices.  Written examinations are used to verify that an employee understands the training material before the process work can be resumed. 
Training documentation includes:  date of most recent review or revision to the training program, type of training required and the type of competency testing used to ensure staff understands the training.  Ongoing employee training records are maintained.

Analysis Scope
The PHA considered all equipment associated with the Anhydrous Ammonia System. The analysis scope included evaluating routine and non-routine procedures such as startup, shutdown, emergency shutdown, maintenance, etc. The PHA also included evaluating operation for potential equipment failures, human errors, and process problems that could result in consequences of interest. However, the Review Team did not consider detailed hazard evaluations of written procedures necessary. Nevertheless, the Review Team did consider recommendations that address procedure-related issues.
The Team used the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) Guideword method in conjunction with What-If /Checklists to provide a comprehensive Hazard Review. This methodology was approved in advance by the CCHD Haz Materials Division. 



Operating Procedures
DEC maintains up-to-date, accurate, written operating procedures that give clear instructions for the ammonia process. Procedures include startup, shutdown, normal operations, temporary operations, abnormal conditions, emergency operations, and emergency shutdown.   The operating procedures also include safe work practices for hazardous material handling.   The operating procedures are accessible to all staff and are maintained in the control room.
If the operating procedures must be modified, the Operations Manager or designee will be responsible for modifying the procedure.  The Operations Manager will review the draft-revised procedures and sign the approval page. Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)
A systematized evaluation of new and existing equipment and processes has and will continue to be implemented in an effort to protect employees, the public, and the surrounding environment.  The initial PHA was conducted on 12/7/2005.  The PHA will be conducted every five years.
The purpose of the process hazard analysis (PHA) is to: 
¿ Identify equipment or process hazards
¿ Identify equipment failures that could lead to accidental release.
¿ Identify staff errors (operations or maintenance) that could lead to accidental releases
¿ Evaluate the consequences of such releases
¿ Identify additional program measures that may be needed to mitigate or prevent the release
¿ Identify additional training and/or safety needs

Emergency Shower and Eyewash. An emergency eyewash and shower are provided a the truck unloading station near the ammonia storage tank. 
Wet Pipe Sprinkler System.  A wet pipe sprinkler deluge water system is provided around the storage tank to dissipate the anhydrous ammonia vapor cloud in case of a leak.  Fire Safe Stop Valve. An emergency fire safe stop valve is provided on the main vapor line from the storage tank to the SCR units.  
Excess Flow Valves.  Each piping connection at the storage tank is equipped with an excess flow valve that will automatically close if the downstream piping ruptures.
Quick Shutoff Valves.  Quick shutoff valves are provided on the liquid fill and vapor return. The valves are electronically controlled from the Control Room and locally at the anhydrous ammonia storage area.

Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
The prevention program elements described in the following section represent integrated administrative controls intended to ensure the safety of workers, the public, and the environment.  The program elements such as process hazard analysis, compliance audits, and incident investigation result in the development of additional safeguards.  Some of the physical safeguards that are part of the original design and are already in place include the following:
Ammonia Storage Tank.  The storage tank is provided with local pressure indicator (in psig) and level indicators (in percent volume).  The tank also has pressure safety valves, temperature gauges, and anhydrous ammonia  leak detectors. Indication and alarms for tank level, temperature, and pressure are displayed on the local control panel and Control Room DCS.  An ammonia vaporizer alarm is also provided in the Control Room DCS.
Secondary Containment. The ammonia  storage tank and vaporizers are located inside a secondary containment area sufficient to contain the full contents of the vessel, 24 hours of rain fall as determined by the 25-year storm and deluge water for 20 minutes as determined by code.
Leak Detection. Four ammonia  leak detectors transmitters are provided and alarm locally and in the Control Room in the event of an ammonia leak. Two leak detectors are located beside the vaporizers and one leak detector is inserted into the PRV line.  A leak detector also is located by the unloading s

ely 20 acres within a 139-acre parcel of land owned by Dow. The 20 acre site is leased to DEC by the Dow Chemical Corp. The site is located in the city limits of Pittsburg in Contra Costa County at the border of the City of Antioch, and is approximately 35 miles northeast of San Francisco. 
The facility currently stores anhydrous ammonia, a regulated toxic substance under RMP and CalARP regulations, in one 15,000-gallon double walled steel storage tank at 85% capacity, which is located inside a secondary containment area.  Anhydrous ammonia is used at DEC to reduce nitrogen oxides (nitric oxide and nitrogen dioxide) created during the combustion of natural gas and exhausted from the three  Combustion Turbine Generators (CTG) and Heat Recovery Steam Generators (HRSG) duct burners.  Anhydrous ammonia  vapor is drawn from the top of the storage tank and diluted with air, and injected into the three Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) units to reduce the NOx emissions. 
The maximum quantity of ammonia stored at DEC exceeds the federal RMP (and PSM) and CalARP specified threshold quantities of 10,000 pounds and 500 pounds, respectively; thus, the facility is subject to federal RMP, PSM and CalARP regulations.  The anhydrous ammonia process is a Program 3 process.

Delta Energy Center, LLC - RMP Executive Summary
Introduction 
Calpine Corporation operates the Delta Energy Center (DEC), a nominal 880-megawatt power plant located in Pittsburg, California.  The DEC uses anhydrous ammonia as a necessary part of reducing the emissions of nitrogen oxides to the atmosphere.  Storing a large quantity of ammonia can be a hazard if it is not handled properly. Calpine Corporation takes its safety obligations in storing and using ammonia as seriously as we take controlling emissions from the power plant. The following document describes what could happen if there were to be an accident, the steps we take every day to ensure a safe operating plant, and what to do in the event of an emergency.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Delta Energy Center maintains a written emergency response program. The program addresses all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, spill response measures, evacuation plans and personnel accounting, notification of emergency response agencies and the public in the event of a release. In the event of an ammonia spill, Delta Energy Center may respond with limited defensive actions.

The emergency response program is coordinated annually with the Contra Costa County Hazmat Agency.

DEC's accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates proven technology, staff training on operation and maintenance practices, and tested management system practices. All applicable procedures of the State of California and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Prevention Program are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response procedures.
